@benjaminion do we have any additional background on this bug? 
At what stage had it happened? (startup, syncing, after restart or anything else) 
Was it seen just once or occurs periodically? 
Any other supporting info? 

The bug looks very mysterious to me for now.

According to my logs, it occured four times within four minutes on August 15th, and has never occurred outside that time. This was about 18 hours after the Medalla incident that made the network quite challenging.

It initially occurred during "normal" slot processing, but throughout this period Teku wasn't seeing any blocks, and was flipping between sync and gossip quite frequently:

```
12:16:36.290 INFO  - Slot Event  *** Slot: 78982, Block:    ... empty, Epoch: 2468, Finalized checkpoint: 2289, Finalized root: d0ea42..255b, Peers: 53

tech.pegasys.teku.core.exceptions.EpochProcessingException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Provided length 8 is too big: the value has only 6 bytes from offset 26
```

If there's nothing obvious, I'd be happy to close this. It may well have been resolved by some of the fixes to fork choice etc. that have gone in since.

```java
node.hashTreeRoot().slice(internalIndex * 8, 8)
```
That's actually very odd case: 
- `the value has only 6 bytes from offset 26` means that the array passed to `ArrayWrappingBytes.<init>` is of length `32` which is expected
- but the offset 26 is odd as it can't be derived from `internalIndex * 8`
- this means that the original `Bytes32` from `node.hashTreeRoot()` had internal byte array of size `32` and `offset > 0` which violates `Bytes32` contract :/

Added additional info in the #2688. 
Closing for now. When/if the issue reproduced again please reopen supplying the info from exception
